awd_titl_txt: CPS:Medium:Hardware/Software Co-Design for the Life Sciences: Towards a Programmable and Reconfigurable Lab-on-Chip
awd_abstract_narration:
This project integrates digital microfluidics with thin-film photodetectors and control software to realize DNA target sensing using fluorescence. This cyberphysical vision is being realized through tight coupling between physical components?the microfluidic platform and miniaturized sensors, and cyber components?software for control, decision-making, and adaptation. Such a level of integration, decision, and controlled reconfigurability is a significant step forward in clinical diagnostics using digital microfluidic biochips. Topics being investigated include: (i) silicon-based digital microfluidics and integration of optical sensors; (ii) closed-loop operation and run-time optimization under software control; (iii) decision-tree architectures, adaptive reconfiguration, and error recovery. A complete testbed is being developed for nucleic acid identification on a fabricated chip with detection sites.


Cyberphysical system integration will transform biochip use, in the same way as compilers and operating systems revolutionized computing, and design automation revolutionized chip design. Benefits to society include the potential to transform personalized medicine, home diagnostics, and portable diagnostics. Integration of digital microfluidics, optical sensing, and software control has the potential to create systems that can be used by any person, regardless of sample preparation skill. One example is the identification of bacterial DNA associated with bacterial blood infection (sepsis), which results in death if not diagnosed early (this is in the top 10 causes of death in the US). Students are being trained through a Senior Design course to understand the design

por.por_cntn:
This project has addressed a key challenge in the advancement of miniaturized lab-on-chip devices for healthcare and molecular biology applications. Sensor integration in microfluidics and efficient hardware/software interaction are necessary for enabling realistic biochemistry on microfluidic biochips. This project has led to fundamental breakthroughs in chip-scale prootocols for DNA processing, as well as the design, fabrication, and testing of optical sesors that are compatible with digital microfluidics. Several new generations of microlfuidic biochips have been fabricated. In addition to advances in hardware, software control and architectural optimization have also been studied. Error recovery based on sensor feedback has been demonstrated--through modeling, simulation, and experimental studies. Dynamic adaptation of on-chip fluidic steps has also been demonstrated for quantitative analysis protocols such as gene expression analysis.

The results of this project have contributed to the closing of the "gap" between microdluidics and microbiology. The design automation advances in this project have been focused on realistic microbiology protocols. Such interdiscplinary research is key to ensuring the commercial exploitation of lab-on-chip technologies 

A sizeable research communty has been developed and nurtured. A Dagstuhl meeting in Germany and a Shonan meeting in Japan were organized on the theme of this project. Microfluidics is now center-stage in all important design automation conferences and features prominently in top journals. A number of keynotes and invited talks at conferences and universities have led to a broader understanding of the science and engineering issues underlying this topic.
